message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the question suggest measles, and the sign that would have been observed prior to the development of the rash is Koplik spots, small white spots on the inside of the cheek. Parotid gland swelling and posterior auricular lymphadenopathy are signs of mumps, and a blueberry muffin rash is associated with congenital rubella syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest measles, and among the options, only Koplik spots are commonly associated with measles. Parotid gland swelling is seen in mumps, posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is seen in rubella, and a blueberry muffin rash is seen in congenital rubella syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and rash pattern suggest measles. Koplik spots are small white spots on the inside of the cheeks that can occur prior to the rash. Parotid gland swelling and posterior auricular lymphadenopathy are more commonly seen in mumps. Blueberry muffin rash is more commonly seen in congenital rubella syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of high fever, runny nose, cough, and red itchy eyes suggest measles, and Koplik spots are a common early sign of measles. Parotid gland swelling is associated with mumps, posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is associated with rubella, and blueberry muffin rash is associated with congenital infections like rubella or cytomegalovirus.

Koplik spots are small white spots that appear on the inside of the cheeks 2-3 days before the rash appears, making it the correct answer. Parotid gland swelling is a common symptom of mumps, posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is a common symptom of rubella, and blueberry muffin rash is a common symptom of congenital rubella syndrome, none of which are consistent with the child's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the fever, runny nose, cough, and red itchy eyes along with the rash extending from the head to the mid-chest level, suggest the diagnosis of measles. Koplik spots are small white spots with a blue-white center that appear on the inside of the cheeks before the rash occurs in measles. The other options are associated with other infections such as mumps (parotid gland swelling), rubella (posterior auricular lymphadenopathy), and congenital infections (blueberry muffin rash).

Koplik spots are small white spots seen inside the mouth that usually precede the measles rash, so if examined prior to the development of the rash, this may have been observed. Parotid gland swelling and posterior auricular lymphadenopathy are associated with mumps. Blueberry muffin rash is commonly seen in congenital infections such as rubella or cytomegalovirus, but not in measles.

These are small white spots with a blue-white center surrounded by a red ring, present on the buccal mucosa, and are pathognomonic for measles. Parotid gland swelling and posterior auricular lymphadenopathy are seen in mumps, while a blueberry muffin rash is seen in congenital infections such as rubella.
